text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm a bit fresh berry fool that's right
I'm going to show you one of my favorite
all-time summer fresh fruit desserts but
before I do I'm gonna answer a couple
very commonly asked questions about this
first why is it called a fool and second
is this so ridiculously simple and easy
that even someone like me could make it
well let me answer both of those
questions by just answering the second
one yes it really is that simple as I'm
just about to prove so let's stop
fooling around and start fooling around
and the first step is going to be to
macerate our fruit and to do that what
we'll do is add our fruit to a bowl and
today I'm going to be using three
different kinds of berries I have some
raspberries which I really think people
should pronounce raspberries as well as
some beautiful sweet strawberries which
I've Holden quartered and then last but
not least I'm also going to add some
blackberries which is you can see I like
to break up first those are a lot bigger
than the raspberries and the centers are
a little bit firm so I do like to break
them up a little bit and then once we're
all set with our fresh fruit we can
continue on with the rest of the
ingredients which we'll start with some
fresh lemon and two forms we'll do some
freshly grated lemon zest as well as a
little bit of the juice as I may have
mentioned about a dozen times before the
great thing about zest is you're getting
that lemon flavor without the acidity
okay it's those essential oils in the
skin that gives you that really strong
lemon aroma and flavor so we will add a
good amount of lemon zest and a little
bit of juice but that's really more for
acidity than it is for the flavor and
then at this point we can go ahead and
add a little bit of sugar and I'm not
actually trying to make a joke relative
to what you've seen a lot of these fresh
fruit Fool recipes that is actually not
a lot of sugar and then we'll go ahead
and grab a spoon and give this a mix and
as I just mentioned this process is
called maceration and which you should
know about that above and beyond that
you should pronounce it very slowly and
carefully maceration simply means
tossing fruit in sugar to dry out those
beautiful natural juices and you'll see
just after a few seconds that the juices
are already starting to come out and
that fruits already starting to break
down a little bit and get nice and shiny
but don't get too excited it's not even
close to ready yet what we're going to
want to do after this is mix is wrap it
up and pop it in the fridge for I'd say
at least an hour or until we think we
have enough juices to make a proper fool
and if you want some
like to do this right on the countertop
at room temperature which does help
extract those juices a little quicker
but since it's summer and I want this
dessert nice and cold I really do prefer
to wrap mine up and pop it in the fridge
and while we're waiting we can go ahead
and prep our cookies and I'm not exactly
sure this counts is prep since basically
we're just going to crumble up some
cookies and know I'm now using vanilla
wafers which are the classic choice I
much much prefer a buttery shortbread
cookie and then the blog post I will
explain why I choose this cookie but to
quickly summarize I think it's superior
to the vanilla wafer in every possible
way but anyway while we're waiting for
our fruit to juice we could just hang
loose or you can prep your cookie crumbs
as shown and at this point we will fast
forward to about an hour later and if
everything's gone according to plan your
fruit should look something like this
all right those berries should have
noticeably slumped you should be looking
at a decent amount of syrup like juice
at the bottom of the bowl and then I
should mention if you want at this point
some people like to take a fork and kind
of crush some of that fruit but
personally I'm not a big fan of mash
fruit so I like to keep my pieces of
fruit pretty much intact just swimming
in those natural juices and then what
we'll do once our fruit is juicy and our
cookies are crumbed we can move on to
the final component the whipped cream
which is going to start with a cup of
cold cream and a cold bowl so feel free
to pop that in the fridge before you
start and then besides our nice cold
cream in bowl I'm also going to add a
little bit of creme fraiche and while
many recipes call for sour cream or
yogurt I much prefer the creme fraiche
as I usually do and by the way because I
am using the creme fraiche I can just
add it at this point if you are using
sour cream or yogurt instead you should
probably fold that in at the end but
anyway I'll remind you of that in the
ingredient list for now let's continue
on with a little bit of sugar and then
we'll finish up with a touch of real
vanilla extract and at that point we'll
go ahead and grab a whisk and whip this
until it reaches the optimum texture and
by far this is the most important step
in the entire operation okay if we under
whip this cream it's going to sort of
break down and we're going to have soup
but if we over whip it and it gets too
stiff that butter fat is going to start
to come out of the cream and it's going
to have a greasy feel on your palate in
fact legend has it that the actor mr. t
was once served this with over whipped
cream and that's where he actually came
up with his famous catchphrase I pity
the fool but anyway the point is not
over with this and what we're looking
for is a mixture that has
pekes but sharp lines so we'll keep
whisking
we'll keep observing we'll keep whisking
we'll keep watching until we get to this
point right here you see all those Peaks
are nice and soft and flopping over but
those lines formed in the surface are
quite sharp and nicely defined so that
is at least for a fool like this
perfectly whipped cream and you will get
a much better look at that in a few
seconds as we move on to final
production so into some kind of
appropriate copper glass we will start
with some cookie crumbs followed by a
spoon of our macerated fruit followed by
our whipped cream mixture and we'll
simply continue on building those layers
until we literally can't fit any more in
this glass now please note we're not
just spooning in fruit make sure you're
getting some juice all right you should
have plenty whoops hold on I almost
forgot we need to add some crumbs here
we definitely want some crumbs in the
middle and I do like to do this
individually in the cups or glasses if
I'm only doing a few if you're making
this for a large group generally the
fruit mixture is folded into the cream
and then just serve from one bowl but if
I'm only going to do a couple I think
they're much nicer like this is I really
don't want these layers too integrated
until I start eating it but of course
that's up to you
you are the Peter O'Toole of making sure
your fool looks cool on one other quick
tip here I really don't recommend
building these on black placemats yes I
had to stop several times the vacuum
those crumbs up which I did by sucking
them up through straw which I did not
film but I should have so we'll go ahead
and finish this up with some more cookie
crumbs and quite possibly a few
strategically placed drips of sauce as
well as I guess more crumbs for whatever
reason I really didn't want to finish
this but eventually I did and that's it
our fresh berry fool is done and
definitely looking like something most
people would want to eat considering the
fact this took very little effort and
even less cooking skills it really does
look impressive but wait that's not all
it also tastes and feels very impressive
so let me go ahead and grab a spoon and
dig in by taking a little taste of that
perfect whipped cream first and right
here you can really see how those layers
kind of merge together as you work this
with the spoon and that's exactly why I
don't like to mix the cream and the
fruit ahead of time when I serve this ok
think by keeping those layers a little
bit separate as you serve it the
experience of eating this is that much
more enjoyable I mean the way our fruity
tart sweet juices kind of mingle with
that Ridge whipped cream is just amazing
that is just an exceptionally enjoyable
spoon of food it's light refreshing just
sweet enough sort of rich and decadent
but not heavy in fact is shockingly airy
but anyway that's it
one of my all-time favorite desserts
using fresh summer fruit and usually
these videos I'm making a fool of myself
well this time I made a fool for myself
